qas.question: About when did the Labour Parry start?
When did it become obvious that the rural proletariat needed a new political party?
What demographic had decreased in number?
What years was the voting franchise shrunk?
Who was the last Lib-Lab candidate to stand?
What socialist group did not form around this time?

context: The Labour Party's origins lie in the <a0_0><b2_0>late 19th century<b2_0/><a0_0/>, when it became apparent that there was a need for a new political party to represent the interests and needs of the <b3_0>urban proletariat<b3_0/>, a demographic which had increased in number and had recently been given franchise. Some members of the trades union movement became interested in moving into the political field, and after further extensions of the voting franchise in <b4_0>1867 and 1885<b4_0/>, the Liberal Party endorsed some trade-union sponsored candidates. The first Lib–Lab candidate to stand was <b5_0>George Odger<b5_0/> in the Southwark by-election of <a1_0>1870<a1_0/>. In addition, several small socialist groups had formed around this time, with the intention of linking the movement to political policies. Among these were the Independent Labour Party, the intellectual and largely middle-class <b6_0>Fabian Society<b6_0/>, the Marxist Social Democratic Federation and the Scottish Labour Party.
